course.subject: MATH
course.name: Differential Equations
course.description: First and second order differential equations, initial value problems, series solutions, Laplace transform, numerical methods, boundary value problems, eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, Sturm-Liouville theory.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131
course.exclusions: MATH 2350, MATH 2351, PHYS 2124

reviews.author: id@a
reviews.title: reg this course when and only when instructor is tklam
reviews.comment_content:
separable/linear/exact first order:
three methods to remember,
separable = obvious,
linear = factor is e^integrate(coef of y)dt,
exact = remember the thing next to dx is pφ/px, another is pφ/py

constant coef linear second order ode and oscillators:
remember formulae "c1ert + c2ert" and "c1ert + c2tert" and "eat(c1sinbt + c2cosbt)"

non homogeneous second order constant coef linear odes:
undetermined coef, reduction of order and variation of parameter.
For undetermined, remember the undetermined coef table
For reduction of order, remember y2 = uy1,
For variation of parameter, v1 = -in(y2g/W) and v2 = in(y1g/W)

series method:
Easy to remember intuitive methods. Also, remember the fact that 2*4*6... = 1*2*2*2*3*2... = 2*2*2...*1*2*3... = 2^n * n!, it may be useful

laplace transform:
learn from blackpenredpen. Make good use of partial fraction and completing square then you don't need to do the f__king annoying convolution.

system of odes:
normal case: e^λt v
complex: Prof jeff chasnov's method is most intuitive, link in "teaching" part
repeated: let another root is e^λt(u+tv), u is vector t is number. then set up an equation by x' = Ax, search on youtube for more details. The video I watch is in teaching part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TLDR: skip all lectures, learn from youtube

attending lectures is a waste of time because:
1. He frequently calculates things wrong and wastes time on finding the problem. Also, much time is spent waiting for him to recall the method. (For example, I remember he spend more than 10 minutes on recalling the proof of variation of parameter)

2. 99% of things taught in lectures won't exist in exams. The only thing you need for the exam is the formulae (general solutions). It saves you more than 50% ~ 90% of the time. I am not saying that the lecture content is not important, but it is very not motivated to learn something that is not fun at all (just some computation stuff) and will not exist in exams.

btw what I believe what I write in the content part should be included with everything needed to memorize already.

2.5 His lecture is not good (not bad at all, but not good enough that it makes you want to join his lecture, esp. when it is a 9 am lecture)

3. If you still can't understand, you can refer to Jeff Chasnov's and blackpenredpen's youtube channels, things are clearly explained there. (btw bprp use methods like partial fraction and completing the square to do those convolution question and I think it is good for the student that not good at integration.)

Jeff (Recommended by TK Lam, very good)
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkZjai-2JcxlvaV9EUgtHj1KV7THMPw1w

Blackpenredpen
https://www.youtube.com/c/blackpenredpen/playlists?view=50&sort=dd&shelf_id=5

Also, I learn the Frobenius method here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yaebm1Gs7Ns&t=1499s&ab_channel=DanielAn

I learn system of ode with repeated eigvalue here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCShTLmeZN4&t=746s&ab_channel=EricCytrynbaum

tbh I may give a C/D to the teaching, but considering that it does not affect me at all, I'd give it a B
reviews.comment_grading:

35% midterm 50% final
Total mean = 71.82% sd = not released
me ~80, B+

The effort I spend is mentioned in the right part, and I get a B+, so I would give it an A.

I look at other review, grade of this course when instructor is not tklam is not good, so i'd only recommend it when instructor is tklam
reviews.comment_workload:
6 Webwork question sets

As mentioned, very light.

For reference, I am bad at computational calculus (e.g. 1014 C+), and I skipped all the lectures (daydreaming, just occasionally looking at the screen). Under these conditions, including the time for learning, I still spend less than 5 hours on each homework, and avg should be 3 hours I guess, so I spend 18 hrs in total on this course this semester, i.e. 1.5 hours per week. I believe for most of you, it is lower than most of your time consumption on a common core.

Midterm and final are quite ez so revision is not required if you are not bad at computation. (I need to revise a little because I am bad though)

Even if you are bad at it, I think one hour of practice per week is enough for the A range. Note that even if you spend one hour on practicing per week, you still spend 2.5hrs per week only :)
(recall: it is a 4 cred course)

reviews.author: JimmyLeung1998
reviews.title: An ok, easy course
reviews.comment_content:
Thz sem we hv
- 1st order, incl integrating factor, separating parameter, exact-ness
- Wronskian, for function independence and as an notation for simplifying formulae
- 2nd order with const coeffs, incl method of undetermined coeff && variation of parameter
- Laplace transform, incl dirac delta, unit step function, convolution for initial value problems
- system of linear differential eqts involving only 1st order derivatives, with emphasis on matrix and eigen-stuff
- Some “physics” applications like spring motion, flowing rate, autonomous eqts, etc

But sth are not incl in exam, and i guess the prof just does not like teaching these in his course, so i leave them here as ref to others.
- Series Solutions, Euler Method. It means the numerical method part in course description would not be tested.
- All those existence, uniqueness thm mentioned in textbook
- Graph for describing solutions
- high order eqt, high order system. It means even there are matrices in exam, they would not be 3-by-3 or above
- PDE. It means the Sturm-Liouville theory, boundary value problems in the course description would not be tested.
- Advanced linear algebra like canonical form. Anything harder than the material in a first course of linear algebra (math 2111/21) are certainly not needed.

As the most complicated topics being excluded, it turns out that thz course afterall is not that hard. In some senses it may be easier than the non-math-maj version of thz course, which is math2351. It is actually gd becoz you can earn a grade for a 4-cred course with a 3-cred effort.
reviews.comment_teaching: Never attend any lectures or tutorial. Just feel not worth spending my summer time for such a computation course... But I did email the prof, asking him some confusing stuff. And i think his teaching or advice is quite okay. And his lecture notes did cover things that are essential to exams. Also those tutorial exercises (which can all be accessed online) are quite useful. So i give it a B to his teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Unbelievably,
- 5% webwork, ie simple online assignment, 5-6 Qs per piece, one piece per week
- 95% final exam

For final exam, maybe becoz of the exam time (early morning...) and the difficultity, in thz sem the overall mean is ~50%. No sd is given, probably becoz of the small class size.

I dont know others mark, but i can tell you mine. My mark is 73/95 in exam, and 5 + 73 = 78/100 in total.  And my final grade is A.

What i m saying is, it can be a gd-grade course, or a bad, all-or-nothing course for different ppl.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 0% attendence, 0% proj, ... in the grading policy. In some sense these make the course sufferable and enroll-able. But notice that the final exam is on an all-or-nothing basis. One cannot simply go for it with only little efforts on those webwork and tutorials.

My advice is,
(i) do revise all the essential linear algebra material. You may not need to diagonalise a matrix, but you do need to know how to solve eqts, determine independence, and handle eigen concepts.
(ii) revise the material in calculus I & II. Mastering 1013/14 or 1023/24 material is a must for you to succeed in this course. A bit of multi-variable functions and chain rule is useful, but not that necessay.
(iii) pay attention to the “physics” problems. I once worried my failure on problems like that on my final exam would lead me to a bad grade... So do revise all the tricks and skills for setting up a solvable equation.
(iv) take the final exam seriously!!! This point is one thing that really I cannot emphasis more. Sometimes if you think you dont hv enough time to do revision, just skip lessons. It can definitely make you more effcient in learning (and relaxing~~).

reviews.author: South
reviews.title: Easy introductory ODE course, suitable for year 1 students
reviews.comment_content: First-order ODE, second-order ODE, Laplace Transform, System of ODE. Since several 1st-year students didn't learn linear algebra before attending this course, stuff involving 3*3 matrix and further are excluded. Hence, yr1 students who do not have linear algebra backgrounds can do well in this course like senior students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Generally good. Although the instructor didn't speak English smoothly, that's not a problem in learning math. It's evident that the instructor is dedicated, and the contents are well organized. He is a nice guy who spent time explaining matrix stuff for yr1 students.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% homework (available on webwork)
80% final exam (there wasn't an mt exam in summer)

The exam is straightforward; I got very high marks. I don't have a lot to say about the grades, but I think it's highly consistent with how much effort you put in.
reviews.comment_workload:
Almost no workload.

4 webwork homework, each takes approximately  30min. However, to get familiar with the contents and do well in the exams, I think you probably have to finish almost all the tutorial questions.

reviews.author: at ease
reviews.title: There are ways to navigate the teaching problems
reviews.comment_content:
Ordinary differential equations (first and second order), initial value problems, boundary value problems, applications of ODEs (mechanical vibrations, damping, and forcing), Laplace transforms, solving for series solutions

Partial differential equations (focusing on the heat and wave equations), boundary value problems

Eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, systems of equations, Sturm-Liouville theory
reviews.comment_teaching:
As mentioned, Prof. Chiang often makes a few mistakes while demonstrating problems during the lectures. He will upload corrected versions of his notes when this happens so it is advisable to go back to each lecture afterwards. The typed notes uploaded before each session are not always focused on the same things as the lecture itself and also sometimes have mistakes in them. Aside from the material, the most important part of the lectures is letting you know which parts of the material have been covered and will show up in your assignments.

Cannot recommend the TA (KW Fong) enough. He was helpful and knew the material well enough to explain it properly and in detail. Before the final he also ran an all-day review session for us. Make the most of your tutorial sessions because it is much harder to get explanations of the same quality during the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework: 10%, midterm: 10%, final: 80%

Homework marks are easy to get if you complete the weekly assignments. I messed up the midterm but got better grades on the final (final grade was B-, not great but within my expectations as I scored very close to mean on both exams).
reviews.comment_workload: Light for a maths course. There is an assignment every week but each one is only a few short questions and should be no trouble for you if you can grasp the material well enough. Take the time to revise ahead for the midterm and especially the final.

reviews.author: Doraemon
reviews.title: Easy Course
reviews.comment_content:
In this semester, the course covered the following topics:

1. First and second-order ODEs
2. Laplace transform
3. System of first-order linear ODEs

The content should be much less than what is mentioned in the course description.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr Avery Ching explains the materials clearly and in good English. He always explains things starting from the most trivial facts. The only thing I would like to comment on is that he spent a whole 3-hour lecture on introducing linear algebra concepts (matrices, linear independence, eigenspaces, etc.) despite the fact that MATH2111/2121/2131 was the official prerequisite for this course. (Well, this also means that you are welcomed to take the course even without the prerequisite.)

Tutorial sessions will be great if you are struggling to understand the concepts during lectures or want more practice or advice. For more able students, you need not attend tutorial sessions at all as the tutor will send all the problems covered during tutorial sessions with solutions, which means it is all fine for you to work on the problems on your own and read the solution whenever needed.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 5%
Final Exam 95%

The homework part comprises 4 web-work assignments, each of which consists of 6 problems. It should take no more than 1 hour to finish the homework after you get familiar with the methods of solving ODEs taught in class. The mean score for each homework was 92.2, 92.36, 91.55 and 100 respectively. (The lecturer has given full marks to everyone in the last homework as he has not reminded us of the homework before its deadline.)

Since this is a summer course, there is no mid-term exam. The final exam consists of 7 problems. All problems (probably except the last) are standard problems that require you to solve a certain ODE or to solve physics problems with the aid of ODEs. The mean of the exam was 65.68%.
reviews.comment_workload: Despite the fact that this is a 4-credit course, the course workload of this course is less than most 3-credit courses I have taken. Among all the MATH courses I have taken, this is probably the one with the least workloads.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Not very challenging, but make sure you have a good background with linear algebra
reviews.comment_content:
Every year has different topics covered based on teaching speed. For this year, the main topics include method of integrating factor for 1st order ODE, exact ODE, 2nd order ODE, high order ODE with constant coefficients, Laplace Transform with convolution integrals, system of linear ODE (linear algebra background is required), and some numerical methods.

Abel's Theorem and variation of parameters have been covered in various types of ODEs.

Textbook used: Elementary differential equations and boundary value problems (Boyce and DiPrima)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wu may not seem to teach very well, but he is very kind and willing to explain every concepts that students do not understand. For example, Jordan Canonical Form is not covered in MATH 2121. Wu has used many lessons to explain the calculations involving Jordan Canonical Form when doing system of linear ODE.

The TA (Yizhe Deng) is very helpful. His tutorial recaps the topic taught in lectures 1 week ago to make sure every one can catch up. He also prepares a pdf which contains the homework problems for us.
reviews.comment_grading:
Textbook and lecture notes (which is nearly the same as textbook) are heavily emphasized by Wu and the TA, and the exams verify their claims. Try to study hard on the lecture notes. The exam is more like proof-based with some tedious calculations. If you don't understand certain proofs, at least memorize them since you may just need to copy again into the answer book in order to get full marks of some questions. I got a decent score in this course, so I couldn't really tell whether this is a "good grade course", but here is the statistics to let you know the average level of students in this class:
Homework (10%): Nearly all people get full marks.
Midterm (25%): Mean 23.43/30
Final (65%): Mean 39.96/62
Total: Mean 70.26/100
(PS I see different statistics from the same semester. This may be due to different tutorial sessions. Take an average of the 2 statistics if you want.)
reviews.comment_workload: Weekly homework and memorization of different methods to solve ODEs and proofs and certain important results are the only workload of this course. (Well, maybe the tedious calculations in homework and exams can be also counted as workload.) So I don't think this course has a high workload.

reviews.title: Easy content but hard questions
reviews.comment_content:
Since it was a summer course, the content was not much comparing to a spring course. There are some similarities and differences.

The first chapter focuses on first order differential equation. Topics include:
1. First order linear differential equations that can be solved by using integrating factors and by the converse of product rule.
2. Separable Equations, simply integrate both sides with respect to the related variables.
3. Homogeneous equations, i.e. the differential equation has the property h(x,y) = h(tx,ty) that can be solved by substitute y=xv, and by product rule can make h be either linear or separable.
4. Exact Equation, that means you can directly think the original equation that satisfy the problem, this part you should practice more.

Chapter 2: Second Order Differential Equations
Topics:
1. Homogeneous Equation with constant coefficients. The skill is to solve quadratic equations, and remember those solutions for three situations, two distinct real roots, repeated real roots and no real roots.
2. Inhomogeneous Equations, you have to guess the original form and solve the coefficients, or using W(x,y), the determinant skill.

Chapter 3: Laplace Transform
I think we should remember the Laplace Transform Table like we have to memorize the first 20 elements in periodic table in secondary school, but the instructor said he would provide the table in the exam which surprised me.

This part introduces a new skill that can transform the ode to another question that simplifies the work. Generally, Laplace Transform can solve higher order differential equations but the instructor only asked us to solve second order differential equations.

Chapter 4: System of homogeneous and inhomogeneous
This part is mainly focusing on solving matrices and dealing with eigenvalues and eigenvectors.

Lastly, if you have no concepts on linear algebra, I recommend you to take course that cover basic linear algebra first, otherwise, you may be confused when you faced questions of chapter 4.

Instructor provided lots of examples but some of them were Physics questions. Of course, ODE is used to solve Physics problems.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Avery Ching is a good teacher but not a good professor.

He focused on the steps in your solution and you cannot argue anything on his marking at all.

When you ask him questions, he cannot provide you an accurate answer, or in Cantonese, we say he is 九唔搭八.
When I learned the topic first order differential equation, we may get troublesome in adding or not adding an absolute sign when integrating 1/x for example. In his solution, he did not add the absolute sign.

He taught lots of Physics questions during lessons, although ODE is really used to solve Physics questions, this is a Mathematics course not "ODE solving Physics Problems". I think he should spend more time in teaching ODE but not those questions. The time he spent on those Physics questions was enough for him to teach a new chapter.

I think I am only a half of water in a cup, in Cantonese 半桶水. So, if you really want to learn differential equations, I recommend you to take the course in Spring semester not in Summer.

reviews.author: fhfui
reviews.title: The WORST final experience (up till now)
reviews.comment_content: I have taken Linear Algebra & Multi-variable Differentiation already. Given that background, I don't feel this course is hard. Personally I am comfortable with skipping all lectures & tutorials, but normally speaking, it shouldn't be hard to follow the instructor.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor's English is good. Details not applicable since I skipped all lectures. But a friend of mine who went to the lectures told this to me:

1. He felt that the professor has conveyed the message of being strict with intermediate steps in the exam. But the professor has never made clear how detailed one should be to gain full marks.

2. Once someone took TA's solution to a problem (or something else) to the professor and asked something. He commented on the solution: "If you write this on your exam paper, you will get one mark deducted." That's it. Quote quote. No why.
reviews.comment_grading:
95% final and 5% webwork since summer term. And let me tell you my experience.

======

During the exam I asked the professor: shall I give detailed argument of this equality, e.g.,
1 / (s+1) / s = 1/s - 1/(s+1) ?

Answer: You decide what you want to say on the paper.

=======

Then I asked: this problem is quite a physics question. Can I use some physics stuff like energy / momentum...?

Answer: You decide what you want to say on the paper.

========

After exam, I got zero point on a spring-and-impulse question. (7 question total so it hurts very much)

Me: The correct answer has taken the impulse into account at the very beginning. Although it was not in my first equation, I included it later below. You can't say I was wrong.

Avery: But you didn't say that when you wrote the first equation.

Me: But I said when I included the impulse.

Avery: But you had a grammar error when you included the impulse (I used the word "delta" instead of "change" in "the impulse results in a change of velocity") so no one understand it.

Me: (WTF) At least I can explain my logic. My logic is not wrong. At least I deserve points for intermediate steps.

Avery: No because your very first equation is wrong. Your following arguments must be wrong.

Me: (WTF) But I considered impulse later on below???

=========

What the heck loop it is? Just because I use another method and wrote a grammar mistake I deserve 0 point?

Even if I get an A-range tomorrow, I cannot accept his refusing to add a single point to this question (14 points, 7 questions in total, 95% final guys!)

And you readers decide whether my above experience is useful or not. I don't care. Definitely E.
reviews.comment_workload: One chapter, one WebWork each week. 4 weeks in total. Fair for a summer course. content and homework are not hard.
